content.body: It is correct, as far as I (a non-native) and my partner (a native) can tell.

Noam Rosenthal: interested in reviewing https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/54227 and https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1847?
Happy to take a look
WebIDL q for the room: is there a specified precedence when the same key exists both in an interface and in "named properties"?
(A web developer was noticing that the behavior of `localStorage.setItem = 'foo'; console.log(localStorage.setItem)` is not interoperable, and trying to decipher what's the spec-compliant one)
content.formatted_body: (A web developer was noticing that the behavior of localStorage.setItem = 'foo'; console.log(localStorage.setItem) is not interoperable, and trying to decipher what's the spec-compliant one)

content.body: Yes, there is
I don't have time right now to work through the algorithm though :)
webstorage/storage_functions_not_overwritten.window.js may be of interest
in wpt
Ha interesting. this is relevant indeed but does the opposite thing (it uses `localStorage.setItem("setItem", value)` rather than `localStorage.setItem = value)`
content.formatted_body: Ha interesting. this is relevant indeed but does the opposite thing (it uses localStorage.setItem("setItem", value) rather than localStorage.setItem = value)

content.body: If you write a test for the other case, I'll try to review ðŸ˜‡
I think I still need to find the spec bit to reason for what the right result is :) Will investigate. Thanks!
Noam Rosenthal: https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#LegacyOverrideBuiltIns can be used to change the order, so `Storage` will behave as if that is not applied; couldn't find a change related to that
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#LegacyOverrideBuiltIns can be used to change the order, so Storage will behave as if that is not applied; couldn't find a change related to that

content.body: Ha ok so for `Storage`, the following should apply: "the usual behavior, which is for named properties to be exposed only if there is no property with the same name on the object itself or somewhere on its prototype chain."
content.formatted_body: Ha ok so for Storage, the following should apply: "the usual behavior, which is for named properties to be exposed only if there is no property with the same name on the object itself or somewhere on its prototype chain."

content.body: I think so, yes
I vaguely remember a former Googler making a point about this on the WHATWG mailing list, so surprising to see that Chrome has a bug here
I think actually chrome does the right thing here and Gecko/WebKit are in the wrong
`localStorage.setItem = 1234; console.log(localStorage.getItem("setItem"))` should return null according to this IIUC. It returns null on chrome but 1234 on FF/Safari
content.formatted_body: localStorage.setItem = 1234; console.log(localStorage.getItem("setItem")) should return null according to this IIUC. It returns null on chrome but 1234 on FF/Safari

content.body: but I guess in this case it's slightly vague in the spec whether a named property that wasn't set yet is "exposed"
I think in that case https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#legacy-platform-object-set applies since it implements setter? Not a 100% sure though.

Ah yes. Storage would fall under the definition of a "legacy platform object" because it's a non-global with named properties. So "setting" `setItem` on it would invoke that algorithm and the result would be 1234 and not `null`. Thanks!
content.formatted_body: Ah yes. Storage would fall under the definition of a "legacy platform object" because it's a non-global with named properties. So "setting" setItem on it would invoke that algorithm and the result would be 1234 and not null. Thanks!
